-Nlcj4H1Y4vUq-rEAAaa.content:
Adam Aakil, Ph.D. in Biomedical Engineering and clinical innovator, is empowering independence and inspiring the next generation of scientific research. He is a highly acclaimed strategist for neuroimaging abnormalities, liver metabolism, breast and prostate cancer.

He also has extensive experience in clinical research of human and animal data targeting microvasculature disorder in the brain structures using a deep learning algorithm programmed in MATLAB for quantitative magnetic resonance imaging perfusion (MRP). He has served as a Research Associate at Boston Medical Center, Boston University School of Medicine, and acted as a Postdoctoral Research Fellow at Massachusetts General Hospital Research Institute.
-Nlcj4H1Y4vUq-rEAAaa.label: Professional Experience

first.description: Christopher Stuetzle, Chair and Associate Professor in Computer and Data Sciences, drives research in three domains: addressing food insecurity through community engagement, refining Federated Machine Learning for healthcare, and using data-driven methods to alleviate traffic congestion.
first.name: Dr. Christopher Stuetzle

-NlcVpil3AUMtHafyk-o.description:
Data-driven Machine Learning (ML) has emerged as a promising approach to building predictive models from medical data, which is collected in huge volumes by modern healthcare systems. Unfortunately, existing medical data is not fully utilized by the industry since there are data silos and privacy concerns with accessibility to the data. Health data are highly sensitive, subject to regulation and cannot be used for research without appropriate patient consent and ethical approval. In addition, these datasets have a significant business value and companies are not willing to share with researchers for the fear of losing a considerable amount of revenue. The main focus of this project is to explore a new technology called Federated Machine Learning (FML), which is a learning method that seeks to address the problem of data sharing, data governance and privacy by training algorithms collaboratively without exchanging the underlying datasets.

FML is a transformative technology that can be a game changer for the healthcare industry with positive impacts for patient health outcomes. The strength of FML is that sensitive training data does not need to be moved beyond the firewalls of the institutions in which they reside. Instead, ML models are created locally at each participating institution (data agent) and only model characteristics are exchanged. Once training has been completed, the trained consensus model benefits from the knowledge accumulated across all data agents. We believe that FML holds significant potential for enabling precision medicine at large scale. The aim of this project is to construct an FML platform, perform and execute FML with different data agents and provide context and detail for the community regarding the benefits, limitations and impact of FML in the context of digital health. We are exploring three different types of FML (horizontal, vertical, and transfer) as well as two structures of execution: a centralized aggregator and peer to peer network.
-NlcVpil3AUMtHafyk-o.title: Federated Machine Learning for Healthcare Data

-Nlc_SUBCxFOBeypebX6.description: Cynthia Carlson, Chair and Associate Professor in Civil Engineering, is dedicated to fostering healthier communities through her research in walkability and public health, water resources engineering, and sustainable infrastructure design. Her focus extends to exploring innovative teaching methodologies, employing hands-on experiential learning to educate aspiring engineers across various age groups.
-Nlc_SUBCxFOBeypebX6.name: Dr. Cynthia Carlson

-Nlc_bfODB-LXe5BX4tn.description: Eleanor Shonkoff, an Associate Clinical Professor specializing in Nutrition and Public Health, focuses her research on child obesity prevention, nutrition, and family health within underserved communities grappling with food insecurity. Her work delves into the connections between parental factors, child dietary habits, and obesity risk, employing mixed methods approaches. Additionally, Shonkoff explores innovative teaching methods like mindfulness while co-founding initiatives like the Food Justice Research and Action Cluster.
-Nlc_bfODB-LXe5BX4tn.name: Dr. Eleanor Shonkoff

-Nlc_jzZtEy1zq2BCFpz.description: Erinn Gilson, Chair and Associate Professor in Philosophy, focuses on ethics in politics, emphasizing gender and racial justice while exploring critical prison studies and ethical considerations in food and agriculture. Her expertise extends to feminist theory and contemporary European philosophy
-Nlc_jzZtEy1zq2BCFpz.name: Dr. Erinn Gilson

-Nlc_ueSXELoLJNWg4K2.description: Sandra Raponi, an Associate Professor, specializes in political and legal philosophy, emphasizing online harassment, free speech, refugee law, and the right to food. With expertise in global justice, human rights, and international law, her background spans Kant's legal philosophy and climate change justic

-NlccuG6QK8LdtFzx9MJ.description: Dan Sullivan, a 2020 computer science graduate, created an encrypted image tool for secure storage and searching. Utilizing Java for the server and JavaScript for the client, the tool ensured privacy while managing images
-NlccuG6QK8LdtFzx9MJ.name: Dan Sullivan

first.description: Zachary Kissel, an Associate Professor in Computer Science, explores the connection between cryptography and complexity theory. His work revolves around encrypted data computation, access control, and innovative cryptographic concepts, particularly in the realm of searchable encryption techniques. Kissel has made notable contributions through various published papers in theoretical cryptography.
first.name: Dr. Zachary Kissel

-NlccSOw1aNlA7CDLdPY.description:
As a semester-long independent project, Dan Sullivan investigated the power and limits of searchable encryption. Searchable encryption is a cryptographic primitive that allows a user to outsource an encrypted collection of data to a third party, but still retain the ability to execute searches over that data in such a way that the server doesn’t learn the user’s search query.

This project resulted in an implementation of a dynamic webpage that allowed users to store encrypted images to be stored on the server while still allowing the user to search over the images without revealing what they are looking for. Beyond simple searching, the searchable encryption primitive was applied to the resizing of images with some success.
-NlccSOw1aNlA7CDLdPY.title: Encrypted Image Tool

-NlcTSqjwxyD8iFv5m1d.description: For the past 20 years, Dr. St. Hilaire has been engaged in basic human research with a focus on combining computational and experimental approaches to understand the impact of insufficient sleep and circadian rhythm disruption on human health and performance. She is an accomplished early-stage investigator who recently served as PI on an NIH-funded R21 as well as a NASA-funded Omnibus award, and currently serves as PI on NIH-funded R01 and R03 awards.
-NlcTSqjwxyD8iFv5m1d.name: Dr. Melissa St. Hilaire

-NlcUcHPVr10h0oyd6RU.description: Laney Tillman, a 2023 graduate student, conducted research focusing on medication adherence among patients with Alzheimer's Disease and Related Dementias, utilizing the Medical Expenditure Panel Survey (MEPS) data
-NlcUcHPVr10h0oyd6RU.name: Laney Tillman

C.description: Medical adherence facilitates medical provider’s decisions regarding the patient’s treatment plan and influences patient outcomes. There is little research that investigates medication adherence in Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD). The purpose of this study is to determine the factors that contribute to medication adherence among patients with ADRD utilizing the Medical Expenditure Panel Survey (MEPS) data.
C.title: Factors Contributing to Medication Adherence in Patients with Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias

-Nlci3P9WaQHTU2L68kE.content: My research interests are at the intersection of cryptography and complexity theory. My research has focused on computing on encrypted data, access control and core cryptographic primitives. I have published several papers in theoretical cryptography, specifically in the area of searchable encryption.
-Nlci3P9WaQHTU2L68kE.label: About me!

-NlcfiX12qHPf508_0VE.content:
For the past 20 years, Dr. St. Hilaire has been engaged in basic human research with a focus on combining computational and experimental approaches to understand the impact of insufficient sleep and circadian rhythm disruption on human health and performance. She is an accomplished early-stage investigator who recently served as PI on an NIH-funded R21 as well as a NASA-funded Omnibus award, and currently serves as PI on NIH-funded R01 and R03 awards. She also serves as co-I on a number of federally funded studies.

She has over a decade of experience conducting highly controlled inpatient studies, the main focus of which have been to apply different sleep-wake schedules to study changes in neurobehavioral performance and alertness under both total sleep deprivation and different patterns of chronic sleep restriction. Her computational work related to these experiments has focused on the development of mathematical models of sleep, circadian rhythms, light and performance, and machine learning and predictive analytic approaches to identifying an individual’s response to sleep loss phenotype and risk of neurobehavioral impairment. She also has expertise in the analysis of multiple hormones measured from blood samples collected during both inpatient laboratory and field-based studies, including female sex hormones.
-NlcfiX12qHPf508_0VE.label: Research Summary

-NlchK6016Z4UbLDg_hX.content:
I have an active research portfolio focusing on three primary areas right now. I am a founding member of the Food Justice Research and Action Cluster (FJRAC). We actively tackle local food insecurity and promote food justice by engaging with community partners and applying our expertise in problem solving efforts in conjunction with their own. The cluster has published papers, run Food Justice Summit events, and exchanged data and resources with community partners.

Federated Machine Learning (FML) is a data modeling paradigm in which models are fit to datasets from multiple sources without the need for those sources to exchange their data, thus protecting the privacy of the subjects in the data. This technique is state of the art and being employed in the finance, education, and especially healthcare arenas. I work on studying and improving the technique with regard to its use in healthcare.

Finally, I am engaged in a multiyear initiative to tackle traffic congestion alleviation using genetic algorithms trained on massive traffic datasets. Fitting language models to the datasets allows for the mapping of roadmap featuresets to traffic patterns, thus determining through automated means how a particular urban traffic pattern will contribute to local traffic.
-NlchK6016Z4UbLDg_hX.label: Research Summary
